articles.title: Extended Stable Updates for Desktop
articles.description:
The Extended Stable channel has been updated to 144.0.7559.173 for Windows and Mac which will roll out over the coming days/weeks.

A full list of changes in this build is available in the log. Interested in switching release channels? Find out how here. If you find a new issue, please let us know by filing a bug. The community help forum is also a great place to reach out for help or learn about common issues.

Srinivas Sista
Google Chrome

articles.title: Stable Channel Update for Desktop
articles.description:
The Chrome team is delighted to announce the promotion of Chrome 145 to the stable channel for Windows, Mac and Linux. This will roll out over the coming days/weeks.

Chrome 145.0.7632.45 (Linux) 145.0.7632.45/46 Windows/Mac contains a number of fixes and improvements -- a list of changes is available in the log. Watch out for upcoming Chrome and Chromium blog posts about new features and big efforts delivered in 145.



Interested in switching release channels? Find out how here. If you find a new issue, please let us know by filing a bug. The community help forum is also a great place to reach out for help or learn about common issues.


Srinivas Sista

Google Chrome

articles.title: Stable Channel Update for ChromeOS / ChromeOS-Flex
articles.description:
The ChromeOS Stable channel is being updated to OS version 16503.74.0 (Browser version 144.0.7559.172) for most ChromeOS devices.

If you find new issues, please let us know one of the following ways:
  1. File a bug

  2. Visit our ChromeOS communities

    1. General: Chromebook Help Community

    2. Beta Specific: ChromeOS Beta Help Community

  3. Report an issue or send feedback on Chrome

  4. Interested in switching channels? Find out how.

Alon Bajayo

Google ChromeOS

articles.title: Gemini Enterprise Agent Ready (GEAR) program now available, a new path to building AI agents at scale
articles.description:
Todayâ€™s reality is agentic â€“ software that can reason, plan, and act on your behalf to execute complex workflows.

To meet this moment, we are excited to open the Gemini Enterprise Agent Ready (GEAR) learning program to everyone. As a new specialized pathway within the Google Developer Program, GEAR empowers developers and pros to build and deploy enterprise-grade agents with Google AI.Â 

Here is how GEAR helps you build whatâ€™s next.

Move from experimentation to production-ready architecture

Building an enterprise-grade agent requires the right tools, planning, and infrastructure. But we also know that to learn these skills, you need the freedom to experiment without watching a meter running.Â 

That is why GEAR membership includes 35 monthly learning credits on Google Skills. This recurring benefit allows you to run labs and test in a sandbox environment, at no cost to you.Â 

Members can use these credits to access end-to-end learning paths designed to help you ship code immediately. Current learning paths available:Â 

  • Introduction to Agents: Understand the anatomy of an agent, how they operate, how they integrate into Gemini Enterprise workflows, and how they fit within the broader Google Cloud ecosystem.

  • Develop Agents with Agent Development Kit (ADK): Go deep on the open-source ADK to build agents that use reasoning loops to deliver predictable, reliable outcomes, moving you from prompting to actual engineering.

Turn technical proficiency into industry-recognized credentials

As you progress through these learning paths, GEAR helps turn your progress into tangible credentials.

  • Earn badges: As you complete agent-focused labs on Google Skills, you can earn completion badges on your Google Developer profile, along with official intermediate and advanced skill badges that validate your expertise.

  • Get certified: For customers looking to certify their skills, Get Certified offers instructor-led training and technical mentorship. This cohort-based program for Google Cloud customers is infused with AI courses, hands-on labs, and skill badges, all designed to prepare you for industry-recognized certifications.Â 

Get started

The transition to agentic AI is a massive opportunity, but it requires a new set of skills. GEAR provides the tools, the credits, and the guidance to help you build whatâ€™s next.

You can access GEAR benefits by creating or signing into your Google Developer Program profile and claiming the GEAR badge.

Get started at developers.google.com/program/GEAR and start your first learning path today.

articles.title: Ask HN: What do you think about the recent Slack UI change?
articles.description:
Slack recently added extra icons to the left of the "Channels", "Direct messages" and "Apps" sections in the sidebar. Previously, this space was left blank until the item was hovered, at which point it would display an arrow indicating collapsibility. Also, DMs with 3+ participants now just feature a single participant count to the left, as opposed to a profile picture of one of the participants with the participant count overlayed off-center.

articles.title: Show HN: Video Forms â€“ turn any YouTube video into an interactive questionnaire
articles.description:
Hi HN

I built Video Forms: a tool that lets you attach questions to specific timestamps in a video, optionally with branching/skip logic.

Motivation: I kept getting â€œlooks goodâ€ feedback on demo/onboarding videos, but the useful feedback was always â€œat 0:42 I got confusedâ€ â€” and it was hard to collect that in a structured way. Surveys lose context; comments are unstructured.

How it works (high level): - You create a â€œvideo formâ€ by placing questions at timestamps (e.g., 0:18, 0:42) - The video can pause to ask the question, then continue - Answers can branch to different follow-up questions based on responses - You get responses tied to the exact moment in the video (and can export/share results)

Use cases Iâ€™m aiming at: - UX research on product demos - Onboarding: â€œdid this step make sense?â€ checks - Training/L&D comprehension checks

Iâ€™d love feedback on: 1) What question types would you need first (free text, multiple choice, rating, etc.)? 2) Is â€œinterruptingâ€ the video a deal-breaker, or does pausing at key moments feel acceptable? 3) Any workflows/tools youâ€™d want this to integrate with?

articles.title: Ask HN: What makes early-stage AI accelerators useful (and what doesn't)?
articles.description:
Hi HN â€” we recently launched the Berkeley Xcelerator (https://rdi.berkeley.edu/xcelerator), a non-dilutive accelerator program run by Berkeley RDI (https://rdi.berkeley.edu/) for pre-seed and seed-stage teams building in AI and agentic AI. Weâ€™d love to get some feedback from the community!

Over the past three years, Berkeley Xcelerator has supported 110+ teams across AI, cybersecurity, and decentralized technologies, whose founders have gone on to raise $650M+ in follow-on funding, spanning 100+ countries.

Some concrete details about the Xcelerator itself:

- The program is non-dilutive (no equity taken)

- Open to pre-seed and seed-stage AI / agentic AI startups

- No UC Berkeley affiliation required

- Selected teams receive support through Berkeley RDIâ€™s research community and ecosystem partners

- Enablement includes cloud, GPU, and API credits from industry partners (including Google Cloud, Google DeepMind, OpenAI, and Nebius, with more to be announced)

- The program culminates in a Demo Day at the Agentic AI Summit (Aug 1â€“2, 2026) at UC Berkeley, where we are expecting 5,000+ in-person attendees

Hereâ€™s what weâ€™d really like input on:

- If youâ€™ve built or joined an early AI startup, what actually helped you most early on?

- If youâ€™ve done an accelerator, what helped and what was a waste of time?

- For technically deep projects (infra, agentic systems, safety-sensitive work), what kinds of feedback or structure mattered most before product-market fit?

If youâ€™d like to apply to the Berkeley Xcelerator, applications are open through the end of February. (https://forms.gle/KjHiLAHstAvfHdBf7)
